There is little room for criticism about the band. Write a positive review about a good movie:  It is an excellent documentary about the plight of women in Egypt. "I want to be an Egyptian," says Shikma, a celebrated feminist writer whose work has been widely anthologized, "I wanted to be the Egyptian." A fascinating documentary about a group of young students who are studying abroad, with whom Shikman and Shikamea (Shikma's best friend) meet, and, in the end, become friends. The documentary is shot in Tahrir Square. But the film's real success is the one when it shows women working in a textile factory. Women make up half of Egypt's population.   The film's director, Faye Nour, said, "The factory girls' union, the women's union, and the political party that organized the protests, these women are all young and, I think, they have nothing to do with the young men who are protesting at the time. This film is for anyone who has never seen a film like this before.  Shikmann's documentary, "Egypt," is just starting. But, as a film that explores an age-old and cruel form of gender oppression, it is not really an indictment of the society or politics at large. Faye's documentary is for those who want to see the "real" story of Shikmah. The young woman's decision to join a political party and go to Tahrir, is not about her ability to make decisions, but about her relationship with the man who is her partner and with the politician who organized the protest. The filmmaker and editor-in-chief of the Egyptian magazine, Women in Cinema: A Short History of the Film Industry, says, "No wonder the film is so short on the subject of violence and the lives of women. There is no time to reflect upon the social and political changes that will have the film lasting impact. Fayes' documentary is about the violence that women have been subjected to in this age-group in general, "the politics that have been used to organize protest."  One of the most striking things about "Egypt" is the way in which it is portrayed as an extremely female-dominated society. Women in the film were not allowed to make up their own minds. Fay's documentary had no value.  It was a sad film to be sure.

It (2007), which tells of a former foster child of a foster family and his subsequent transition to adult life. The film was in English (the native language of the cast). The filmmaker also showed an American (the only native-born in the cast) in the film who had been abused by a previous foster family. His abuse is horrific as she struggles to heal herself of her childhood trauma. The man's abusive behaviour towards his children is deplored as he attempts to do so.  Heavily supported by the film-makers (aside from the actors) the film tries to present the children's lives with insight into how difficult it is to do this. The director's aim in releasing this film is to try and present their lives in a way which minimises the pain felt by the children, while presenting them as if their lives were theirs to begin with and allowing their lives to become independent of their families.  I think this film really succeeded in that task. The only problem with that endeavour is how the film could have been more comprehensive in addressing the suffering experienced by children with no parents and no siblings. It may have had the same impact on the lives of the parents who loved their children.   This film tells of the life of the man who was abused by the foster family, yet it is a poor film for all its attempts to present all life with compassion, empathy and understanding. It is not the documentary as the film portrays a negative view of the child's life.  The film tries not to present these issues as a documentary. It shows the lives and experiences of the two adults as if they were their own. But, as I said, the documentary shows the cruelty of the abuse. This documentary is not a documentary, but is a very ordinary documentary that explores the cruelty which children's parents inflict on children. The children were, in fact not harmed by other children. They suffered the same abuse as they were abused as they had previously.  My personal view is that this documentary is the kind that people who are abused in foster care have experienced. I think most people are too naive to see the cruelty and trauma they experience. The violence, pain and pain endured by these children were not a result of their own childhood.

Write a positive review about a good movie:  It's the first feature of this film is an excellent documentary about John Hughes (whom the critics have dubbed a genius director) in his first years of directing. The filmmakers do so without addressing the historical, political, psychological or artistic context which, the director argues, Hughes was at best capable of. The film explores the psychological mechanisms by which artists (as writers, directors, actors, etc) reach an audience who are in search of meaning and closure. In the end it feels like a movie of a painter (who could paint such a thing?) making an art of his art and of the experience that is artistic in itself.  The film has great power of language (which is so important for the director) and of visual storytelling. At a basic level it reveals how art and life can create a singular and overwhelming experience. The director's primary concern is how art (as written and filmed) can change the way people experience and interact with each other. The audience, through the spectator, experience the creative process. At the same time it also makes a statement of art and creative process which is unique in its genre and time.  It was not easy to get people to sit through and participate in this experience. They are not told that this was a film that anyone could watch and then become part of the creative team.  I found the film interesting from a distance and it's a wonderful experience to watch.
